This changed from a third-party import to a project import so it should go in the last section: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#import-order-template

Same for all the other files.

Also, I'm not sure calling it "logging" is a great idea since it looks quite different than plain logging. Maybe "sched_log" so it would be sched_log.start(), sched_log.emit(), sched_log.clear().

nova/scheduler/log.py.message: I'm still not super sure why the is configurable....

I think the main reason would be for people that are worried about the performance penalty of generating the logs.

If there is a consensus that this should be unconditional then I'm happy to remove the config option.
could we make this a real object, if we did, we could loop the list and mark the ones we emitted as sent, then do a separate delete sweep.
oops, that was supposed to be a tuple.  What's the benefit of being able to mark the ones that were emitted?  Would you propose doing multiple passes or something?
what happens if things are added to _log_records when it emits to disk? Is this just an explode? Shouldn't we be operating on a copy?

I asked about this but didn't get a lot of response.  Do we need to worry about simultaneous parallel scheduler operations in different eventlets, or does the scheduler run one _schedule() operation to completion and then start another?  If we could potentially have many of them going on at the same time, then we need to change the code to make _log_records a per-eventlet variable.  Once we can guarantee that then this shouldn't be a problem because we only call emit_logs() once we're done the scheduler operation.
why are the logs upgraded to info? Shouldn't they keep their original level?

Some operators have said they can't run at "debug" log level because there are too many logs emitted.  The idea here was to allow running at "info" log level, but then emit additional logs in the case of a failure to schedule.
Is there any concern that clear logs happening after now contains more items?
It shouldn't...what did you have in mind?  The idea here was that once you've emitted the logs there's no reason to cache them anymore.

These aren't following the openstack hacking guidelines [1]. Should be:

 import copy
 import logging
 import sys
 import types


 from oslo_log import log as oslo_logging


 import nova.conf

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#import-order-template
Why do you want this to be different than the superclass and exclude extra?

Shouldn't this method call the superclass first? The source has:

 kwargs["extra"] = self.extra

and with this, that would be lost
that's very ugly, why not using the traceback module for example ?
Agree that it's ugly, will take a look at traceback.

here, I could be a bit worried to see a new oslo.log version modifying the internal APIs so that the inheritance would be trampled - even silently.

Probably we should figure out another approach to just pile the logs in memory without really needing to inherit from oslo.log.

I'm less worried about the inheritance (we really only use debug() and info()) and more worried about getLogger and logger_handle_override().

How can we preserve the original log location without some intimate knowledge of the internals of oslo_log?

Some good point was made during your unconference discussion about using the RequestContext for persisting in memory the logs. That would be another direction that wouldn't need to use the internal oslo.log interface.

Are you thinking we could do that while still preserving the LOG.debug() API?

It would also have the nice property of being naturally per-eventlet.

nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_log.py.message:
I don't like this because a significant part of the change is the custom adapter, so I think we want to run that code.

Here's a local change I did to check the actual log output instead. What do you think?

http://paste.openstack.org/show/523689/
I think the "should not log" test should be a separate test case, so you don't have to clear the adapter before testing it.

nova/virt/hardware.py.message: why is this changed outside of the scheduler?

Maybe because of:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/331306/1/nova/scheduler/filters/numa_topology_filter.py@18

? But yeah this looks wrong.

I agree, it's kind of wonky.

This code is called from within numa_topology_filter.py, and so when it's called from there we want to be able to cache the debug logs and emit them only if the scheduler operation fails.  When called from elsewhere we want to log immediately.

If you've got any ideas on how to accomplish that more cleanly, I'm open to suggestions.
not sure I understand why this change is needed here... Because of the NUMAFilter?

For the NUMATopologyFilter the functions in virt.hardware do all the interesting checks, so if we don't include their debug logs in the sched log pipe we get basically no useful information for that filter.

Since the NUMATopologyFilter is one of the most complicated filters (with some non-obvious failure modes) it would be a real shame if we didn't actually provide useful logs for this filter.
Oh, saw comments in PS1. Well, I don't think we should add the virt.hardware logs into the sched log pipe.

I'm really not a fan of having to change the imports in every module to suit the schedular. IMHO there needs to be a way to get the schedular logging config setup, without having to futz with imports in all code modules that happen to contain methods that might be run from the schedular.

I agree, it's not elegant.

What if we monkey-patched the logging routines in the hardware module when importing it from the scheduler code?  Still not elegant, but at least the changes would be limited to the scheduler code.

Any suggestions are welcome.

we won't remove this which would result in a PUT schema 400 error.
Should this include action='append' so you can specify more than one provider to remove?

I have a use case :)

We have a case in our CI cloud downstream (openstack) where some messed up migrations resulted in allocations on three different resource providers. And we're looking to delete the allocations from two of the three providers. So, being able to specify the two RPs would let us do it with one command run instead of two.

> I have a use case :)
 > 
 > We have a case in our CI cloud downstream (openstack) where some
 > messed up migrations resulted in allocations on three different
 > resource providers. And we're looking to delete the allocations
 > from two of the three providers. So, being able to specify the two
 > RPs would let us do it with one command run instead of two.

Ack, yeah, I think eandersson (blizzard) has reported something similar when they were upgrading to rocky and had a bunch of orphaned migration-based allocations from moving servers around and something failing and not cleaning up properly on each migration attempt. I think I told him to just delete them all and run heal_allocations since that would be easier.

I'll add append for this and write a test for it.
Honestly speaking I don’t come up a use case for that now, but I say yes because it is easier to change it now than to add the feature in the future with our compatibility culture.
FWIW, the current supported version is 1.22. Though I don’t think we should -W this before 1.28, I prefer to catch up with it before the release. Let’s just work on.

We don't really have to follow the supported API microversions in order like python-novaclient does. That's more of a process thing and how nova CLI works (the CLI defaults to the latest negotiated microversion that the server and client understands), but OSC doesn't work that way so as long as you can specify a version and it works we're OK.
Good to add malformed uuid check and accept CAPITAL uuids also, that said this isn’t sent, checked or normalized in the server side.

> If you specify a provider that
 > doesn't exist on the CLI you'll likely get a 400 or 404 from the
 > server which is correct behavior.

Note that this is not 400 or 404. Having wrong uuid on this value will be a silent error since it is not passed to the server. This is why I don't think validation is that too much here.

I wondered if users get confused when they create resource providers with something like:

    openstack resource provider create rp1 --uuid 377EB9E7-AFFF-42C3-B687-DE67C98E776C

and/or set inventory and/or create allocation with that kind of capital uuid, find it works properly, and then find that something like:

    openstack resource provider allocation set --no-provider 377EB9E7-AFFF-42C3-B687-DE67C98E776C

doesn't work as expected, since "<capital_uuid> !=<actual_uuid>" ...

Agree that this is a corner case and validation may be too much, but it may help someone to have just a bit normalization of lower()'ing the value.

I got the path and the test for 1.28 added in this patch works thanks to the following patch [1]. This is fine.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695048/1

But we have to support 1.23-1.27 before we actually support 1.28, right?
...but assuming it is okay to have gaps since user can opt things, this change looks good to me. Thanks for addressing my comments.

> But we have to support 1.23-1.27 before we actually support 1.28,
 > right?

No, that's not really how OSC works since it defaults to the base microversion (1.0) and the user has to opt into whatever version they want to use. python-novaclient is different in that it defaults to the highest negotiated version between the client and server for the CLI (but not the API bindings in novaclient). So we can have gaps in OSC - see how many there are for the compute API in base OSC:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/compute-api-microversion-gap-in-osc

osc_placement/tests/functional/test_allo.message: note: this generation is not of the consumer but of the resource provider. Ideally we want a test to reproduce 409 with the racy condition, but since it is difficult from client side, this looks good enough to me.

I don't like that we're explicitly expecting the generation to be incremented by one. That's relying too much on the internals of how placement deals with generations, which (although it's not likely to happen) we have reserved the right to change without a microversion (to e.g. use random numbers or hashes or whatever).

It would be better simply to assert that the new generation is not equal to the old generation. But that's a bit of a PITA to do.

So I'm okay with the (negligible) risk that Placement will break this in the future and we'll have to fix it.
That 409 race would have to be mocked b/c it's a super tight window to hit that with how this command works.

octavia/controller/worker/v1/tasks/datab.message:
We should not add notifications to the database layer.
These are only used for the amphora driver, so third party provider drivers would never send any of these notifications.
Also, adding them to existing tasks means these tasks can't be used for non-user facing tasks such as managing spares pools, etc. If we decide that adding notifications to the flows is the correct design, we should add unique notification tasks to the flows.

Thank you very much for your prompt feedback! I added the code to send end notifications here because I want them to be sent immediately after the status changes, which happens in the database layer. 

Could you please elaborate how we can make the design flexible enough such that third party provider drivers can send those notifications as well? I used notifier from oslo_messaging to send notifications. To enable notifications, we only need to set notification driver to 'messaging' in the config file. Notifications in other openstack projects such as trove and karbor are also implemented in this way. I personally don't see the necessity for octavia to be adaptable to other notification drivers.    

Moreover, would you mind explaining "non-user facing tasks" and how sending notifications here will make them fail in more details?

Thank you very much for taking the time!

octavia/network/drivers/neutron/floating.message: Reusing vip.port_id to hold the flip_id... Could make a new column, but seems like overkill since in many cases it is actually very nearly the same kind of object.

When create a loadbalancer I specified --vip-net parameter like:

openstack loadbalancer create --vip-net Ext-Net --name lb1

After all the vip port has been created and here it tries to allocate the the floating_ip on the same network_id as Ext-Net.

I would like to have possibility to specify on which network I want  create a VIP port (afair named 'octavia-lb-vrrp-%nova_inst_id%) and after all to specify from which subnet I want to add floating ip for this vrrp port.

For now it creates FIP from the same net and I faced two issues because of that:
1) My neutron doesn't like it, due:

NotFound: External network 6ed4d34f-0b07-43c7-a1f9-14a0c7e9c8d7 is not reachable from subnet 0d39ebc9-bde6-41b3-af1f-796e967eb3c1.  Therefore, cannot associate Port 8bb5294f-531c-4d2a-944e-a6eff4b2 with a Floating IP.
But the network and the subnet basically is the same. 

2) By using it I allocate 2 IP addresses for 1 purpose. 


Can't we try to add possibility to distinguish networks, like:

openstack loadbalancer create --vip-subnet Priv-Net --fip-subnet Ext-Net --name lb1?


Yes, I can achieve the goal using:

openstack loadbalancer create --vip-subnet Priv-Net --name lb1

and then allocate the FIP on octavia-lb-vrrp, but if this driver is intend to do the same, why not to make it working like this?

Hey,
Yes, when you specify the FLIP driver loadbalancer shows the FLIP as the loadbalancer IP, thats right. There is no other entry as you said.
But on the bottom there is another port created (VRRP port in service tenant) with allocated IP address (for example Public IP address) that is unused.

Yea, I know that adding new parameter like --flip-network id of --flip-subnet-id requires API changes :(

Lets talk about it on Meeting.

The point of the FLIP driver is that the FLIP *is* the VIP, there is no other entry into the LB... so when you specify Ext-Net as the VIP network, that is saying "I want the FLIP to be on Ext-Network". If you want the flip to be on a different network, specify that network instead. There is no other vip-port. VIP port == FLIP. I could see adding the ability to select a subnet using `--vip-subnet-id` and that would work fine, my users would just skip providing that. I can make that change.

doc/source/user/metadata.rst.message: Would be good to get confirmation that the limit really is 65535 base64 characters (and not 65535 bytes of data in a base64 representation). If so, then maybe it would be even better to say how much unencoded data that is (my math says 49151 bytes, but a human-friendly lower approximation like "roughly 47 kilobytes" would be better still).

And it looks from the schema like the data stored in that field in base64 encoding, not decoded before it's stored, so per my original comment it may make more sense to say "47 kilobytes of data before encoding" rather than expecting the reader to do the math themselves (or even realize that there's a difference).

It's the size of the column in the DB:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b96b385a3468e91fa544bffa51832513feb4f383/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/servers.py#L215

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b96b385a3468e91fa544bffa51832513feb4f383/nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L288
BTW, that number is based on math.floor((6/8)*65535/1024).

Great suggestions.  Unfortunately I have no idea where this limit comes from, so I can't check it.  I suspect it's coming from some middleware, because I see the same limit documented for flavor descriptions:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-flavor-detail#create-flavor

Can anyone else chip in here?

oslo_utils/strutils.py.message: An alternative approach to this might be to add a unit tests that verified all the _SANITIZE_KEYS are lowered. Then we wouldn't need the duplication and it could still be verified.

hmmm, that would allow to avoid a duplicated dataset indeed.

For the unit, a comparison of the original set to a lowered one should be enough, right?

must
should imply "it's OK with other things".

Not sure to see the benefits to remove that...

Sanitize test will help to formalize things by forcing lowercase but personnaly I'm not a big fan to expect something from a comment in the code who ask for formalize.

Often comments are not updated or forgotten and they don't really reflect the real situation while code him is explicite in this kind of situation and code like this avoid any doubts.

I really prefer keep the `lower` function calls and they are compatible with the sanitize test part.

Thoughts?

> Not sure to see the benefits to remove that...

Simply to remove the extra processing as this code will be executed many times. Granted, it may be a premature optimization.

I created this follow up after the feedback from Ben on my previous patch. It might provide some extra context; https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694515/


 > Sanitize test will help to formalize things by forcing lowercase
 > but personnaly I'm not a big fan to expect something from a comment
 > in the code who ask for formalize.
 > 
 > Often comments are not updated or forgotten and they don't really
 > reflect the real situation while code him is explicite in this kind
 > of situation and code like this avoid any doubts.
 > 
 > I really prefer keep the `lower` function calls and they are
 > compatible with the sanitize test part.
 > 
 > Thoughts?

I'd rather use Dougal proposal in order to enforce the lower keys in the _SANITIZE_KEYS:
- calling "key.lower()" (and derivatives) are OK, but we need perfs in here. cpu cycles, and so on. Might be best to avoid the [key.lower() for key in _SANITIZE_KEYS] for that same reason.
- the unit-test will fail if someone doesn't follow the "rule", with a message we can understand easily
- how many new key have been added in the past?

For the sake of KISS and cpu cycles, it's better to ensure all is entered as lower chars and run a one-time unit test upon changes than, during each class call, re-map the content.

My intent was to add something like this:

_SANITIZE_KEYS = [k.lower() for k in _SANITIZE_KEYS]

here so that we still enforce the lower-casing, it just doesn't have to happen every time through the loop.
Yup, I had done this in patchset 2. It then occurred to me that a unit test might make more sense. However, happy to revert to that. I don't have strong feelings.

Oh, hah, I should have looked at the unit test changes too. I'm fine with the unit test solution as well. If anyone is modifying this list at runtime then they've done something very naughty and deserve whatever they get. :-)

diskimage_builder/lib/dib-run-parts.message:
Well, for the sake of not adding full arg parsing to this patch and the fact that if you use --list, --verbose will do nothing I decided to shortcut this.
However, if we agree to make the checks on by default this can go away anyway.

originally, dib-run-parts was part of "dib-utils" and split out because it was considered a generically useful runner.  but for years the only thing in dib-utils was this script, which was only used in "instack".  it became an increasing pain having dib depend on this and increasingly clear the idea that "dib-utils" would grow into something wasn't happening.  so we moved it back into here as a private tool

thus, long story short, i think we're ok with slightly odd semantics as it's not intended to be an external tool.  but if we don't, so much the better.
